ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better understanding of the French culture as a whole (politics, education, religion, etc.)

The course provides a thorough overview of French culture. It expanded my vocabulary to allow for engaging discussion of real-world issues: labor issues, the evolving modern family, regionalism and nationalism, and immigration and integration among others. As a non-French and non-European person, it can be difficult to understand French culture, but the course forced me to interrogate the origins of cultural misunderstandings and develop a much more nuanced perspective. We got there through a mlange of readings, shorting written assignments, exposs and films. If nothing else, the course introduced me to a wide variety of super interesting French media, particularly some unforgettable films. Of course, the course also offers many opportunities to practice your spoken French.
Learned a lot about French culture and society

Gained a lot of useful insight into French and francophone culture, society, and politics. Was a really useful and interesting way to gain a real understanding of the issues we hear about in the news so often in France in particular.
Practice French, with an emphasis on conversation and culture. This is not a grammar course (very different from 150)
I learned how to improve my conversational french while also learning a lot about francophone culture.
Developed a broader vocabulary to discuss a range of topical subjects. My confidence in speaking French conversationally also improved dramatically.
The ability to speak French fluently (sh).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Good discussions with the class, almost always very engaging and interesting. 

Weaknesses: A lot of weekly assignments (in addition to other classes) and sometimes lectures would run on for a long time, being a little tiring (especially over Zoom).

Strengths: The course offers a deep dive into French culture, and it manages to do a thorough overview even with so much content to cover. Vocabulary lists are actually really useful, and much of them will stick with me. Like most language courses, particularly in the French Dept., the course is super well-structured, and there's rarely any surprises. The workload is just enough to be manageable while also engaging, considering that the class only meets 2 days a week. I had no problem watching all the films, since they were genuinely really interesting. The readings offer a lot of interesting perspectives, too. Mme Sherak does a good job of challenging your ideas so that you're forced out of your comfort zone and think about things from different POVs.
Weaknesses: Minimum vocabulary quotas in the writing prompts felt a little bit juvenile given the course level, but that depends on your skills with the language. The class wasn't that large (maybe 10ish people, maybe a few more at the beginning of the semester), but given that the class time is so short, and only meets twice a week, you don't have too many chances to speak. That might just have been a symptom of Zoom, though.
Strong course the only issue was it being on zoom because some of the personal connection was lost .
Considering the virtual format, this class went well

I thought this was a great course to help students improve their french speaking skills. I thought a main weakness was related to the fact that we were on zoom instead of in person in a seminar where interaction is pivotal, but that couldn't have been changed and we had to adjust.

The films we watched were well selected - this was reflected in the long and engaging discussions we had about them in class. The oral exams also felt a good way to consolidate the confidence in speaking we'd been working on during the semester. Although the class purported to be based in discussion around topics relevant to French and francophone culture, the focus was definitely concentrated on France, which left discussions on other parts of the francophone world cursory and somewhat shallow. The topics for both the written and oral exams were very vague and the prompts required reference to multiple topics, which also made it difficult to engage more seriously with an idea or argument - the responses necessarily ended up being more like summaries of basic ideas around the topics of the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Wish it were in person as it was a smaller seminar, however breakout rooms and engaging discussions made the class more enjoyable (even over Zoom).

I thought that the presentations that our professor had us share with the class throughout the semester was a great way to give students an extended period of time to practice their expression in french orally. In terms of improvement, it would be difficult sometimes to uphold a flowing conversation because of the virtual environment.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If they are looking to learn about the different lenses of French culture through lots of films and readings.

Yes. At some point in your language journey, you have to graduate from grammar classes and fill-in-the-blank homework. This course provides you with the tools to make interesting conversation, engage with controversial topics and immerse yourself in French culture. It's definitely necessary for anyone hoping to master the French language and use it professionally in the future. Also, the final oral requires you to conduct an interview in French with a French-speaking person. Super cool and informative.
I would because it greatly improves language skills

Yes, definitely! It gives you a lot of confidence in communicating in French but more importantly, about discussing broader societal issues in France in general. We  talked a lot about the idea of lacit, which ties into the strict French laws around religious headscarves; we discussed regionalism in France and how there are countless languages spoken across the country and how the government has historically pushed to make french the national language at the expense of regional cultures; we talked about education and the lack of resources in banlieues  all of which, to me, has been extremely invaluable.
Yes, I would. It is a difficult french course but it is very helpful in improving your conversational skills.
Yes, I'd recommend it to someone wishing to improve their spoken French.
Yes. If they're looking to use French in a variety of domains
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
